LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Islamic Republic of Afghanistan 
   
Classification  Targeting classification: General intervention 
Sector: Transport and communications 
Subsector: Roads and highways 
Theme: Sustainable economic growth 
Subtheme: Fostering physical infrastructure development

Project Description  The  Project  is  to  (i)  rehabilitate  the  Mazar-e-Sharif–Dara-i-Suf 
road  (140.3  kilometers  [km])  and  the  Bamian–Yakawlang  road 
(98.9 km), (ii) install cross-border facilities in Spin Boldak, (iii) 
support campaigns to prevent HIV/AIDS and increase awareness 
of human trafficking; (iv) provide support for project management 
and monitoring, and (v) provide project management support to 
the Ministry of Public Works (MPW).  
 
Rationale  Since rehabilitation of roads started after more than two decades 
of conflict, the focus of the road rehabilitation program has been 
the reconstruction and completion of the regional highways. Once 
the  current  or  planned  projects  are  completed  by  2008,  the 
existing regional highway network will be improved to a two-lane 
bitumen-paved road standard, with certain four-lane sections near 
Kabul  and  Kandahar.  In  contrast,  more  than  90%  of  national 
highways  and  provincial  roads  are  either  earth  or  gravel,  and 
more than 60% are in poor condition. Many are impassable at 
specific locations such as rivers and where severe erosion or 
landslides have occurred. Except for newly constructed bridges, 
most bridges and culverts along national highways and provincial 
roads are in bad condition. Many are in danger of collapse from 
heavily loaded vehicles or of being washed away.  
 
The Government’s next priority is development of the north–south 
and east–west corridors, which connect the ring road horizontally 
and  perpendicularly  and  improves  access  for  people  living  in 
remote areas at the center of the country.  
 
During the first phase of road rehabilitation, after resuming its 
operation in Afghanistan in 2002, the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) gave priority attention to rehabilitation of regional highways, 
particularly  the  ring  road,  with  emphasis  on  trade  links  to 
neighboring countries, including bridges, disintegrated pavement, 
drainage  erosion  protection,  and  routine  maintenance.  With 
rehabilitation  of  regional  highways  nearing  completion,  ADB  is 
placing   priority    on   connecting   the   ring   road   through    the

ii   
  north–south corridor or the east–west corridor as recommended 
by  the  road  master  plan  prepared  with  ADB  assistance.  The 
project roads comprise the north–south and east–west corridors, 
which connect the central of the country to the major cities such 
as Mazar-e-Sharif and Kabul, through which the ring road passes. 
 
Afghanistan has made significant progress since the ouster of the 
Taliban regime. The Government has implemented a wide range 
of  structural  reforms  and  adhered  to  almost  all  quantitative 
indicators and structural benchmarks under the Staff-Monitored 
Program, led by the International Monetary Fund. Notwithstanding 
these achievements and sustained economic growth over the last 
2  years,  the  economic  and  fiscal  situation  continues  to  be 
extremely fragile. Security, economic, social, and administrative 
challenges are formidable. Afghanistan continues to need external 
development finance that does not fiscally burden the nascent 
administration. To achieve growth targets over the medium term, 
the  Government  must  aim  for  broad-based  and  sustainable 
development and identify new drivers of growth. Investment in the 
road sector is a prerequisite for sustained economic growth, and 
the grant will greatly help accelerate this transition.  
 
   
Impact and Outcome  The Project will help the Government to promote economic and 
social  development,  and  reduce  poverty  by  rehabilitating  the 
national highway network to connect the central remote regions of 
Afghanistan to the ring road.  
   
Project Investment Plan   The investment cost of the Project is estimated at $140.9 million, 
including taxes and duties of $1.7 million.  
   
Financing Plan  A loan of $78.2 million and a grant of $40.0 million from ADB’s 
Special Fund resources will be provided. The proposed loan will 
have a term of 40 years, including a grace period of 10 years, with 
an annual interest rate of 1% per annum. The total amount of the 
interest charge during the grace period will be capitalized and 
charged to the loan account. The grant will finance (i) resettlement 
costs,  (ii)  civil  works  for  the  Bamian–Yakawlang  road,  (iii) 
campaigns to prevent HIV/AIDS and human trafficking, and (iv) 
incremental project management support. The loan will finance (i) 
civil  works  for  the  Mazar-e-Sharif–Dara-i-Suf  road,  (ii)  cross-
border facilities, and (iii) project management and monitoring.  
 
The ADB loan and grant totaling $118.2 million will finance 84 % 
of  the  project  cost,  excluding  land  acquisition,  and  taxes  and 
duties of $2.7 million, which will be incurred by the Government. 
The Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction will provide an additional 
grant  of  $20  million  to  finance  civil  works  for  the  Bamian–
Yakawlang road.

Implementation  The  Project  will  be  implemented  by  the  existing  Project 
Arrangements  Management Unit, which handles the ongoing ADB road projects. 
MPW  will  assign  a  team  of  two  engineers,  one  land/revenue 
officer,  and  one  office  administrator  to  the  site  offices  of  the 
project management consultants so that they can liaise with the 
project management consultants, contractors, local governments, 
and people in the project areas. MPW staff, stationed in the field, 
will handle day-to-day project implementation.  
 
The component of cross-border facilities will be implemented by 
MOF’s Customs Department. The director general of the Customs 
Department  will  be  responsible  for  day-to-day  project 
implementation. 
 
MOPH will implement the component on HIV/AIDS prevention and 
anti-human trafficking awareness campaign. 
 
   
Procurement  Procurement of goods, services, and civil works to be financed 
under the ADB loan will be carried out in accordance with ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines. Civil works contracts will be procured 
through  international  competitive  bidding.  A  single-stage,  two-
envelope  procedure  (without  prequalification)  will  be  used. 
Equipment for cross-border facilities will be procured by limited 
international  bidding.  All  international  procurement  will  be 
undertaken by the Government procurement unit operating under 
the Afghanistan Reconstruction and Development Services.

Consulting Services  Two consultant teams and two individual consultants will be hired 
to  help  MPW,  MOF,  and  MOPH  implement  the  Project.  The 
consultant teams will (i) oversee overall project management; (ii) 
supervise  construction  and  installation  of  equipment,  including 
reviewing detailed designs prepared by contractors; (iii) supervise 
implementation of the HIV/AIDS component; (iv) certify completed 
works by contractors; (v) provide on-the-job training for MPW staff 
assigned to the consultant team; and implement and supervise 
the training component of the Project; and (vi) undertake benefit 
monitoring and evaluation. The individual consultant will assist (i) 
MPW and the Afghan Reconstruction and Development Services 
in evaluating the technical and financial proposals for supervision 
consultants, evaluating the proposals for civil works contracts, and 
preparing  final  bid  evaluation  reports;  and  (ii)  the  Customs 
Department of MOF in supervising procurement and installation of 
cross-border facilities. All consultants financed from the ADB loan 
will  be  selected  and  engaged  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. 
   
Project Benefits and  The Project will lead to both direct and indirect poverty reduction 
Beneficiaries  impacts. The direct poverty impact will be on income generation 
and  demand  for  unskilled  labor  and  wages  accruing  during 
construction of the project road. Other benefits will be lower travel 
time  and  travel  costs,  and  higher  agricultural  product  profit 
margins.  
 
Improved roads will lead to a shift from subsistence agriculture to 
market-based  production  enabling  farmers  to  grow  perishable 
commercial products like vegetables and fruits and transport them 
more quickly to markets. The farmers in the provinces will be able 
to  diversify  their  cropping  patterns;  cultivate  high-value  crops; 
grow larger marketable surpluses to improve their income earning 
capacities;  and  generate  more  agricultural  wage  employment, 
particularly benefiting the poor. 
 
Improved  road  conditions  will  lead  to  growth  of  affordable 
transport  facilities  and  thus  the  poor,  especially  women  and 
children will have more reliable, affordable, and timely access to 
educational and medical facilities. Lower transportation costs will 
increase  mobility  among  the  poor  to  find  employment 
opportunities  in  other  areas.  Increased  access  to  local  and 
national markets will lead to growth of local trade and production 
activities,  and  reduced  prices  of  agricultural  commodities  and 
other products.

v
  The benefit of the improved road in terms of reduction of vehicle 
operating costs will not only be transferred to the road users but 
will  decrease  accident  deaths  and  disabilities  that  result  from 
extremely poor road conditions. Thus increased economic activity 
and easy access to social services are expected to significantly 
increase household incomes and quality of life thereby reducing 
overall poverty incidence. 
 
Risks and Assumptions  The  risks  are  related  to  (i)  the  Government’s  continued  weak 
implementation  capacity,  including  the  timely  provision  of 
counterpart  personnel;  (ii)  the  prevailing  security  situation, 
including  a  recent  increase  in  activities  by  antigovernment 
elements; (iii) possible increased trafficking of narcotics along the 
improved roads; and (iv) an increase in HIV/AIDS transmission 
and/or human trafficking as a result of improved road connectivity 
and increased movement of people.  
 
These  risks  will  be  mitigated  to  the  greatest  extent  possible 
through (i) allocation of resources under the Project for consulting 
services to facilitate project management and implementation, as 
well  as  continued  technical  assistance  to  MPW;  (ii)  continued 
close  monitoring  and  coordination  with  local  and  central 
authorities, United Nations agencies, and International Security 
Assistance Force and coalition military establishments to ensure 
adequate  exchange  of  security-related  information;  (iii) 
improvement of border procedures to contain narcotics trafficking; 
and  (iv)  development  of  mitigating  measures  by  the  project 
component for the HIV/AIDS prevention and anti-human trafficking 
awareness campaign.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
loan, (ii) a proposed grant, and (iii) proposed administration of a grant to be provided by the 
Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, in each case to the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan for the 
North–South Corridor Project. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
 
1.  Road Infrastructure 
 
2.  Afghanistan  is  a  landlocked  country.  With  a  large  area  (about  652,000  square 
kilometers)  and  an  estimated  population  of  22.8  million  widely  spread  across  the  largely 
mountainous terrain, roads are the principal means of transport. The road network comprises 
about 3,300 kilometers (km) of regional highways, 4,900 km of national highways, 9,700 km of 
provincial roads, 17,000–23,000 km of rural roads, and about 3,000 km of urban roads including 
1,060  km  in  Kabul.  Regional  highways  (comprising  the  2,300  km  ring  road  that  connects 
Afghanistan’s  major  regional  centers  [Herat,  Kandahar,  Mazar-e-Sharif,  Maymaneh,  and 
Sheberghan] with Kabul, and the roads linking to neighboring countries) foster regional trade 
and economic linkages between Afghanistan and neighboring countries such as Iran, Pakistan, 
Tajikistan,  Turkmenistan,  and  Uzbekistan.  National  highways  extend  regional  highways  to 
provincial capitals contributing to economic growth and national integration. Provincial roads 
improve the administrative, trade, and economic contacts between district headquarters and 
respective provincial capitals, and between important district headquarters; while rural roads 
bring remote areas into commercial contact with markets.  
 
3.  Since rehabilitation of roads started after more than two decades of conflict, the road 
rehabilitation program has focused on reconstruction and completion of regional highways. 
Once the current or planned projects are completed by 2008, the existing regional highway 
network will be improved to a two-lane bitumen-paved road standard, with certain four-lane 
sections near Kabul and Kandahar. In contrast, more than 90% of national highways and 
provincial roads are either earth or gravel, and over 60% are in poor condition. Many are 
impassable at specific locations such as rivers and where severe erosion or landslides have 
occurred.  Except  for  newly  constructed  bridges,  most  bridges  and  culverts  along  national 
highways and provincial roads are in poor condition. Many are in danger of collapse from 
heavily loaded vehicles or of being washed away.  
 
2.  Road Transport Service 
 
4.  The number of vehicles has increased significantly over the past 2 years. According to 
statistics  provided  in  a  recent  International  Monetary  Fund  country  report  on  Afghanistan, 
transport of goods by road increased from 1.9 million tons in 2000, to 3.7 million tons in 2001 
and 5 million tons in 2002, representing an almost fourfold increase. The number of taxicabs 
nearly  doubled  from  17,000  in  2000  to  33,500  in  2002.  More  than  147,000  vehicles  are 
estimated to be registered in Kabul. Most vehicles are owned and operated by the private sector 
as the Ministry of Transport-operated fleet has been severely depleted.  
 
5.  The Afghan private sector has historically played a dominant role in trucking and has 
maintained its presence, including individuals and firms that relocated in Pakistan during the war

2   
years. Long distance public transport, linking major cities and neighboring countries, which 
deteriorated due to road and vehicle conditions as well as suppressed demand for road travel, 
has been regaining its role. However, security remains a key impediment for its full-scale 
restoration of operations.  
 
6.  Urban  transport,  once  dominated  by  the  public  sector,  is  now  mostly  provided  by 
privately owned buses, taxis, and minivans, but with little regulation. It is constrained by lack of 
transport capacity; congestion, pollution; lack of accessibility; inadequate route coverage; poor 
road condition; and lack of depots, stops, and terminals as well as designated road space. The 
urban transport system needs integrated planning. Vehicle fleet support services are mostly 
privately  provided,  with  government  workshops  operating  poorly,  including  those  at  border 
points. Forms of regional transport depend on the state of the roads and the availability of 
vehicles.  People  and  goods  move  together,  blurring  distinction  between  passenger  and 
commercial freight traffic. Private agencies operate provincial and district routes. Some 165 
registered long-distance private bus companies are estimated to be operating—101 based in 
Kabul, 64 in the provinces—with a total of 14,007 buses, mostly old minibuses and vans. 
 
3.  Road Sector Management 
 
7.  The Ministry of Public Works (MPW) is responsible for development, operation, and 
maintenance of regional highways, national highways, and provincial roads in the country. It had 
a large engineering organization with staff stationed in every major provincial capital carrying 
out work through force account. Over the course of the conflict, MPW lost most of its trained 
staff. The current staff of 2,900 require substantial skill enhancement to perform their duties. 
The Ministry of Rehabilitation and Rural Development is responsible for development of rural 
infrastructure,  including  rural  roads.  Municipalities  are  responsible  for  the  construction  and 
maintenance of urban roads. 
 
8.  The Ministry of Transport regulates the private sector transport industry. With a current 
staffing level of 1,180, the ministry’s primary function now is coordinating agreements between 
private sector and international transporters, and establishing offices in neighboring countries to 
facilitate international trade. The ministry’s private sector department sets technical standards 
for private commercial vehicles and inspects them for compliance during the licensing and 
renewal process. It collects a fee of 5% per carriage contract from private trucks and 3% per trip 
from interprovincial private buses, based on authorized charge rates. These fees are collected 
at national or provincial borders or the outskirts of major cities.  
 
9.  Appendix 2 presents an analysis of the road sector.  
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
1.  Government Strategy for Road Sector Development  
 
10.  The Government has identified reconstruction and rehabilitation of the road system, 
especially of regional highways, as the country’s top priority in reconstruction. Since 2002, with 
external assistance, the Government has been making massive efforts to reestablish the road 
network, particularly for regional highways, to facilitate provision of basic social services to 
remote provinces, to provide security, and to involve all the population in undertaking nation-
building  activities.  Afghanistan  is  receiving  extensive  assistance  from  the  international  aid 
community to reconstruct and develop the road network. For regional highways, almost $1.2 
billion has been provided or committed to rehabilitate 3,100 km of roads. These rehabilitation

3
works will be completed by 2008. For national highways, about $270 million has been provided 
to reconstruct and improve 1,200 km of roads. These commitments are mainly to rehabilitate 
damaged roads. 
 
11.  Anticipating the work on regional highways to be completed by 2008, the Government’s 
next priority is development of the north–south and east–west corridors, which connect the ring 
road horizontally and perpendicularly and provide better access to people living in remote areas 
in  the  center  of  the  country.  The  Government  is  preparing  the  priority  road  development 
program for the next 10 years (2006–2015) in line with the recommendation of the road master 
plan being prepared with Asian Development Bank (ADB) assistance.1 The least-cost option 
recommended by the road master plan envisages (i) upgrading 281 km of high-traffic regional 
highways  to  4  lanes,  (ii)  improving  2,700  km  of  high  priority  national  highways,  and  (iii) 
improving  5,000  km  of  high  priority  provincial  roads.  The  required  road  expenditure  to 
implement the recommended option is $1.7 billion, excluding ongoing projects with financing 
resources secured.  
 
2.  ADB’s Strategy 
 
12.  ADB places its first priority on rehabilitating the road system, which is critical for a 
landlocked country. According to the Initial Country Strategy and Program (2002–2004),2 roads 
are needed to rebuild the economy by establishing major economic linkages domestically and 
with neighboring countries. The strategic direction for the rehabilitation, reconstruction, and 
development of the road sector comprises (i) policy and institutional development; (ii) capacity 
building;  (iii)  private  sector  development;  (iv)  employment  generation;  (v)  community 
participation; (vi) decentralization of network management; (vii) sustainable sector financing and 
cost  recovery;  (viii)  protection  and  preservation  of  the  environment;  (ix)  avoidance  and 
mitigation of resettlement; and (x) involvement of returnee refugees, ex-combatants, women, 
and the nongovernment organization (NGO) community in road construction and maintenance.  
 
13.  During the first phase of road rehabilitation, after resuming its operation in Afghanistan in 
2002, ADB gave priority attention to rehabilitating regional highways, particularly the ring road, 
with  emphasis  on  trade  links  to  neighboring  countries,  including  bridges,  disintegrated 
pavement, drainage erosion protection, and routine maintenance. As rehabilitation of regional 
highways is completed, ADB is focusing on connecting the ring road through the north–south 
and east–west corridors as recommended by the road master plan (para. 11). This is also in line 
with the Government’s priority investment projects identified for the national transport program. 
Accordingly, the Project is included in the Country Strategy and Program Update (2006–2008).3  
 
3.  External Assistance and Aid Coordination 
 
14.  The ring road is being rehabilitated with financial and technical assistance (TA) from 
bilateral  and  multilateral  funding  agencies.  The  United  States  Agency  for  International

Kabul–Kandahar road. USAID, and the Japanese and Saudi Arabian governments provided 
financing  for  rehabilitating  the  Kandahar–Herat  road.  The  World  Bank  and  the  Islamic 
Development Bank provided support for rehabilitation of the Kabul–Doshi-Pul-e Khumri road,

4.  Road Maintenance 
 
16.  Routine  road  maintenance  expenditures  are  projected  to  increase  steadily  as  road 
projects are completed: from $8 million in 2006 to $25 million in 2015. Periodic maintenance will 
not be required until 2010, when expenditures will increase significantly to about $45 million per 
year  from  2011  to  2015  when  the  regional  and  national  highway  projects  currently  under 
construction will require their first periodic maintenance.  
 
17.  The most immediate maintenance requirement is for special maintenance works on 
national highways and provincial roads of which maintenance has long been delayed, beginning 
with an estimated $26 million in 2006 and gradually decreasing to $14 million in 2015 as the 
backlog of work is eliminated. During 2006–2015, the need for special works will decrease while 
the need for routine and periodic maintenance will increase, approximately balancing each 
other. During 2006–2010 the average annual requirement for routine, periodic, and backlog 
maintenance ranges from $34 million to $47 million; this will increase to $87 million for 2011–
2015 because of the significant increase of periodic maintenance. 
 
18.  The expected road revenue falls far short of the required road maintenance expenditure. 
The  main  source  of  road  revenue,  road  tolls  which  the  Government  will  reinstate  for 
rehabilitated regional highways, is expected to generate $13 million–$23 million for 2006–2015 
on the basis of the toll rate of $0.005 per passenger car equivalent per km. Even considering 
vehicle registration fees currently collected and expected to generate $3 million–$6 million per 
year during 2006–2015, the expected road revenue will be able to finance about 30%–50% of 
the road maintenance requirement.  
 
19.  To relieve the shortfall of road revenue, the Government will evaluate other sustainable 
methods for revenue generation such as setting up a dedicated road maintenance fund based 
on fuel levies, vehicle licensing, and other road-user related taxes; and will complete this 
evaluation by December 2007. At present, fuel prices in Afghanistan rank among the lowest in 
the region (about $0.5 per liter) with no tax levied except customs duty of 9%. Taxes on fuel in 
other  countries  range  from  13%  to  70%.  Based  on  fuel  usage  and  estimated  number  of 
vehicles, the total amount of fuel used for road transport is estimated at 582 million liters per

5.  Capacity Development  
 
20.  Upon  resuming  its  operation  in  Afghanistan  in  2002,  ADB  focused  its  efforts  on 
strengthening the capacity of MPW to implement aid-assisted projects. ADB has taken the 
approach of assigning a team of international and domestic experts to MPW to compensate for 
MPW’s lack of capacity to implement large-scale projects, and provide on-the-job training for 
MPW  staff.  Under  the  ongoing  TA  cluster  for  Capacity  Building  for  Reconstruction  and 
Development,5 ADB is providing such assistance for MPW to strengthen its capacity to plan and 
manage projects. Under the Emergency Infrastructure Rehabilitation and Reconstruction Project 
and the Andkhuouy–Qaisar Road Project, the Project Implementation Unit established within 
MPW is gradually building capacity to handle day-to-day project implementation with the aid of 
project management consultants. Several MPW staff have been attached to the contractor and 
the  supervision  consultants  to  receive  on-the-job  training  in  project  administration  and 
implementation.  
 
21.  Although this arrangement of capacity strengthening worked well and contributed to 
building MPW’s capacity for project management, it focused on immediate needs for project 
implementation  with  little  regard  to  long-term  sustainability  of  these  efforts.  Building  basic 
capacity immediately after the civil strife and conflict might justify various piecemeal measures 
to quickly attend to urgent requirements. However, as MPW’s operation is normalized with its 
attention shifting to long-term planning and quality control of road works from quick rehabilitation 
of damaged roads, the paradigm for capacity building of MPW needs to be changed from 
meeting immediate needs to establishing a sustainable arrangement that is self-sufficient, with a 
minimum of external support.  
 
22.  ADB’s  capacity  building  assistance  is  now  designed  to  set  up  a  self-sustainable 
mechanism in strengthening MPW’s capacity for road sector management. Under the 2005 TA

MPW staff and engineers in the local construction industry, and design exchange programs

6.  Subregional Cooperation for Transport Corridor Development 
 
24.  Afghanistan’s efforts to rehabilitate and reconstruct its shattered road network have 
drawn much attention from its neighboring countries. An improved road network in Afghanistan 
will  result  in  an  improved  transport  network  in  the  subregion.  Landlocked  Central  Asian 
republics are showing great interest in establishing transport corridors through Afghanistan to 
warm-water ports on the Arabian Sea and Gulf. Iran and Pakistan are rapidly developing their 
ports and improving roads connecting to the ports in expectation of increased import/export and

subregions,  South  Asia  and  Central  Asia,  becomes  more  critical  with  Afghanistan’s  active 
participation in regional cooperation initiatives. 
 
25.  ADB  has  been  actively  involved  in  this  subregional  initiative  to  develop  effective 
transport corridors. Under the TA cluster (footnote 5), ADB provided assistance to develop a

establish the Central and South Asia Transport and Trade Forum9 in 2003 as an instrument for

trade. Under the TA for Cross-Border Trade and Transport Facilitation approved in 2004,10 ADB 
assists Afghanistan in developing an instrument to facilitate the smooth transportation of goods 
across the corridors linking Afghanistan with neighboring countries.

8.  Opium-Related Problems 
 
30.  Poppy cultivation and downstream narcotics production and trade constitute a major 
threat to Afghanistan’s security and stability as the trade in opium, including opium debt, ties the 
poor rural population to regional warlords and international crime syndicates. Afghanistan’s drug 
economy continues to represent nearly half of the country’s total licit economy. As such, control 
and  eradication  of  opium  poppy  production  and  narcotics  trafficking  represents  a  huge 
challenge to Afghanistan’s reconstruction and development.  
 
31.  Afghanistan is the world’s largest producer of illicit opium, comprising 87% of world 
production, or some 4,200 metric tons. Narcotics also constitute the largest sector of the Afghan 
economy; valued at $2.8 billion, the opium economy equaled some 60% of the country’s 2003 
gross domestic product ($4.6 billion, if only licit activity is measured). Opium is a major source of 
cash income for farmers because of the high profitability of opium poppy compared with other 
agricultural crops, as well as the lack of livelihood alternatives in rural areas. In 2005, more than 
2  million  Afghans,  or  nearly  10%  of  the  country’s  total  population  were  estimated  to  be 
somehow engaged in the production of opium.  
 
32.  The  Government’s  overall  antinarcotics  strategy  is  to  eliminate  the  production, 
consumption, and trafficking of illicit drugs into, within, and from Afghanistan, focusing on the 
provision of alternative livelihoods for Afghan poppy farmers, extension of drug law enforcement 
throughout Afghanistan, implementation of drug control legislation, establishment of effective 
institutions,  and  introduction  of  prevention  and  treatment  programs  for  addicts.  The 
development partners are contributing to the Government’s antinarcotics efforts with a focus on 
alternative livelihoods, including rural credit to address problems of opium debt, as well as 
support  for  improved  law  enforcement  and  interdiction  and  legal  and  judicial  reform.  The 
development partners are also attempting to mainstream the antinarcotics agenda into other 
development activities.

9.  HIV/AIDS13 Prevention Strategy 
 
35.  HIV/AIDS prevalence, as reported by the Ministry of Public Health (MOPH), is 51 HIV 
cases and 4 AIDS deaths (as of 2006), although many more cases in the country’s 22 million 
population  could  go  undetected  and  unreported.  The  National  HIV/AIDS/STI  (sexually 
transmitted infection) Control Program, adopted in July 2003, is currently being revised and the 
first  draft  of  the  National  Strategic  Plan  of  HIV/AIDS/STI  Control  (2006–2010)  has  been

10.  Lessons Learned 
 
37.  A number of lessons can be drawn from past ADB emergency assistance projects, best 
practices, as well as ADB’s initial lending and nonlending operations in Afghanistan since 2002: 
(i) continued emphasis has to be given to capacity building to improve planning, project design 
and implementation, administration, and financial management; (ii) aid coordination through 
government-aid consultative groups or other mechanisms is important to avoid duplication or 
delays; (iii) aid groups must work closely with a country’s finance ministry and central bank to 
develop a viable and working payment system, without which maintaining a flow of funds is 
difficult; (iv) capacity building in executing agencies is vital, and consulting services for project 
design and implementation should explicitly provide for the training of executing agency staff in 
the  operation  and  maintenance  of  rehabilitated  facilities;  (v)  the  number  of  procurement 
packages should be minimized, given the limited implementation capacity for project execution; 
(vi) ADB’s procurement guidelines should be applied flexibly to allow reduced procurement 
periods for the urgent delivery of project components; and (vii) law and order situations resulting 
from conflict hamper the smooth implementation of projects, and detailed security plans must be 
in place to address possible security hazards in project locations. From experience with project 
implementation in Afghanistan, lessons include (i) procurement actions need to be taken far in 
advance to expedite implementation, and (ii) recruitment of consultants should be expedited. 
These lessons of experience are fully incorporated in the project design, and in particular, 
procurement actions will proceed in parallel with project processing to avoid any start-up delay 
of project implementation. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
38.  The Project will help the Government promote economic and social development and 
reduce poverty by rehabilitating the national highway network, which will connect remote areas 
in central Afghanistan to the ring road. The project roads pass through Balkh, Bamian, and 
Samangan provinces, which are located at the center of the country and characterized by 
mountainous terrain with altitudes up to 3,500 meters (m). The population of these provinces is 
about 1.7 million, comprising 8.4% of the total Afghanistan population. Rural farmers make up 
about  90%  of  the  population;  the  urban  population  comprising  the  remaining  10%  is 
concentrated in large cities such as Bamian and Mazar-e-Sharif. In Bamian and Dara-i-Suf, 
production of coal reserves and iron ore deposits will lead to growth of the mining industry in the 
region, decreasing dependence on agriculture.  
 
B.  Outputs 
 
1.  Rehabilitation of the North–South National Highways

and  the  Bamian–Yakawlang  road  (98.9  km),  which  comprise  the  north–south  corridor 
connecting the ring road through central Afghanistan. The Project will improve the project road 
to a two-lane asphalt-paved standard that will allow smooth passage of heavy vehicles. The 
typical cross section suggested for flat and rolling terrains is 3.50 m wide, with two granular 
shoulders of 1.5 m and two verges of 0.5 m, with a total width of 11.0 m. In mountainous terrain,

3.  HIV/AIDS Prevention and Anti-Human Trafficking Awareness Campaign 
 
42.  The  Project  recognizes  the  importance  of  preventing  HIV/AIDS  as  a  crosscutting 
development issue, which is linked to and exacerbated by the human trafficking issue. The 
program to combat trafficking will help mitigate the spread of HIV/AIDS, and hence is included in 
the HIV/AIDS prevention and human trafficking awareness campaign. The Project will support 
implementation of an evidence-based communication strategy on HIV/AIDS prevention and 
control in Afghanistan that will be developed by MOPH with the assistance of the United Nations

awareness and prevention initiatives to target high-risk groups including injecting drug users 
and commercial sex workers, young people and adolescents, contractors, construction workers, 
and communities along the corridor of influence. Briefing sessions for imams and mullahs will be

C.  ADF IX Grant Component 
 
45.  Under the ADF IX resolution,14 donors agreed that Asian Development Fund (ADF) 
grants could be used to assist poor countries make the transition from postconflict to peace and 
stability. Afghanistan was identified as one of the poorest postconflict countries and eligible for 
ADF  grants. 15  Prolonged  conflict  has  endangered  the  poor,  destroyed  their  economic 
opportunities, damaged infrastructure, and disrupted delivery of basic services to the neediest. 
The  Bamian–Yakwalang  section  of  the  Project,  due  to  its  remoteness  and  harsh  weather 
conditions, is still in need of continued humanitarian aid and assistance in basic social services. 
Improvement to the road, along with other grant-financed components of resettlement, public 
campaign on HIV/AIDS and human trafficking, and project management support, will facilitate 
access to such social services and provide better access to markets for agricultural produce and 
lower transportation costs thereby contributing to development of some of the poorest areas in 
the region.  
 
46.  Afghanistan has made significant progress since the ouster of the Taliban regime. The 
Government has implemented a wide range of structural reforms and adhered to almost all 
quantitative indicators and structural benchmarks under the Staff-Monitored Program, led by the 
International Monetary  Fund. Notwithstanding these achievements and sustained economic 
growth over the last 2 years, the economic and fiscal situation continues to be extremely fragile. 
Security, economic, social, and administrative challenges are formidable. Afghanistan continues 
to need external development finance that does not fiscally burden the nascent administration. 
To achieve growth targets over the medium term, the Government must aim for broad-based 
and sustainable development, and identify new drivers of growth. Investment in the road sector 
is a prerequisite for sustained economic growth, and the grant will greatly help accelerate this 
transition.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
 
A.  Social and Poverty Impacts 
 
68.  In Afghanistan, nearly 53% of the population are classified as poor22 and live on less 
than $1 a day. The project road passes through the provinces of Balkh, Samangan, and Bamian 
and will benefit a total population of 1,735,800.23 Before the war, these provinces were known 
for their agriculture, livestock, handicrafts, and carpet industry. The existing road condition is the 
biggest constraint as people are unable to transport their products to market and currently crops 
are grown on a small scale only for household consumption. Poverty in these provinces is 
estimated to be 60% with the majority of the population living in mud houses (80%–95%) 
without electricity, clean water, proper sanitation facilities, and garbage disposal system. As per 
the data available, only 10%–11% of the households in these three provinces had access to 
clean water; only 10% in Balkh province had a garbage disposal system. The social assessment 
indicates that the population living along the proposed alignment is generally poor with about 
48% having an annual income of less than $600 with an average household size of 9. The 
survey also indicates that 75% were engaged in subsistence agriculture and allied activities for 
their livelihood, while the rest had small businesses in the town areas.  
 
69.  The Project will lead to both direct and indirect poverty reduction impacts. The direct 
poverty  impact  will  be  on  income  generation  and  demand  for  unskilled  labor  and  wages 
accruing during construction of the project road. Other benefits will be lower travel time and 
travel costs, and higher agricultural product profit margins. Improved roads will lead to a shift 
from subsistence agriculture to market-based production enabling farmers to grow perishable 
commercial products like vegetables and fruits and to more quickly transport them to markets. 
Improved road conditions will lead to growth of affordable transport facilities and thus the poor, 
especially  women  and  children  will  have  more  reliable,  affordable,  and  timely  access  to 
educational and medical facilities. Lower transportation costs will also increase mobility among 
the poor to find employment opportunities in other areas. Increased access to local and national 
markets will lead to growth of local trade and production activities, and reduced prices of 
agricultural commodities and other products. Thus increased economic activity and easy access 
to social services are expected to significantly increase household incomes and quality of life 
thereby reducing overall poverty incidence. The summary poverty reduction and social strategy 
is in Appendix 11.

C.  Economic Analysis 
 
71.  The  economic  analysis  was  conducted  separately  for  the  two  district  roads  in 
accordance with ADB's Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects. The highway design 
and maintenance model (HDM-IV) was used to calculate vehicle operating costs and time costs 
with modification for conditions in Afghanistan. The major inputs include vehicle characteristics 
and related costs, and construction and maintenance costs. The major benefits are derived from 
savings of vehicle operating costs and travel time due to rehabilitation of the project road, which 
will provide a stimulus for economic growth in the project area.  
 
72.  The economic evaluation resulted in an economic internal rate of return of 29.8% for the 
Mazar-e-Sharif–Dara-i-Suf  road  and  20.7%  for  the  Bamian–Yakawlang  road.  The  Project’s 
economic costs include the resource costs for traded and nontraded costs, materials, and labor. 
All cost elements are valued at border prices, using a world price numeraire, with all taxes and 
duties excluded. A standard conversion factor of 0.95 was applied to the financial costs of 
nontraded inputs to calculate economic prices.  
 
73.  The sensitivity of the economic internal rate of return for the project roads was analyzed 
with respect to changes in the benefit and cost streams such as (i) construction costs increase 
by 20%, (ii) benefits decrease by 20%, (iii) no time savings considered, (iv) no diverted and 
generated traffic, and (v) the combination of (i) and (ii). The results show that the quantified 
economic benefits are robust to various sensitivity tests for the overall project road, even in the 
worst case of no diverted and generated traffic. Details of economic analysis are in Appendix 
13.

E.  Risks 
 
77.  Implementation of the Project entails a number of risks: 
 
(i)  The overall political and security situation remains volatile. ADB will need to closely 
monitor the situation and coordinate with local and central authorities and the United 
Nations to ensure adequate protection.24 ADB’s TA for the Security of ADB-Financed 
Projects  in  Afghanistan  will  provide  advice  on  how  to  ensure  a  safe  work 
environment for on-site personnel assigned by the contractors, subcontractors, and 
consulting firms. Under the prevailing conditions, however, this security risk cannot 
be mitigated completely, and delays in project implementation, if security hazards 
occur in project locations, will be inevitable. 
 
(ii)  Regional warlords and militia leaders retain their military strength and consequent 
influence in regional politics. Such political instability could hamper smooth supply of 
raw  materials  and  equipment  transported  through  areas  controlled  by  regional 
warlords and militia leaders, and could constrain supervision of construction works 
by the consultants and ADB staff.  
 
(iii)  Improved roads can be used as a route to transport opium. As part of the national 
counternarcotics strategy, the Government will improve border procedures to contain

B.   Vehicle Fleet and Road Transport Industry 
 
4.  The number of vehicles increased significantly over the past 2 years. According to 
statistics provided in a recent International Monetary Fund country report,2 transport of goods by 
road increased from 1.9 million tons in 2000 to 3.7 million tons in 2001 and 5 million tons in 
2002, representing an almost fourfold increase. The number of taxicabs nearly doubled from 
17,000 in 2000 to 33,500 in 2002. More than 147,000 vehicles were estimated to be registered 
in  Kabul,  which  under  certain  assumptions  would  translate  into  about  304,000  vehicles 
countrywide. Most vehicles are owned and operated by the private sector.

5.  The Ministry of Transport (MOT) is the road transport regulator, road transport service 
provider, as well as policymaker. It regulates the private sector transport industry and manages 
the government-owned vehicle fleet. Before 1978, freight and long distance bus services were 
left to the private sector, while the public sector played a role in the Kabul bus service. New 
legislation in 1978 authorized the Government to provide nationwide freight and passenger 
services.  In  1990,  MOT  reportedly  controlled  1,600  trucks,  1,000  buses,  and  extensive 
workshops. During the conflict, however, almost all fleets were lost. MOT provincial checkpoints 
that once tracked performance and location of its fleets and all other traffic now only monitor 
private vehicles. 
 
6.  With  a  current  staffing  level  of  1,180,  MOT’s  primary  function  now  is  coordinating 
agreements between private sector and international transporters, and establishing offices in 
neighboring countries to facilitate international trade. MOT is structured to have 10 departments 
under the minister and two deputy ministers. Over 70% of the staff is in the private sector 
department, which sets technical standards for private commercial vehicles, inspects them for 
compliance during the licensing/renewal process, and collects a carriage fee from private trucks 
and  a  trip  fee  from  interprovincial  private  buses.  These  fees  are  collected  at  national  or 
provincial borders or the outskirts of major cities.  
 
7.  The  Afghan  private  sector  has  historically  played  a  dominant  role  in  trucking  and 
maintained its presence, including individuals and firms that relocated in Pakistan during the war 
years. Long distance public transport, linking major cities and neighboring countries, which 
deteriorated due to road and vehicle conditions as well as suppressed demand for road travel, 
has been regaining its role. However, security remains a major impediment for full restoration of 
operations.  
 
8.  Urban  transport,  once  dominated  by  the  public  sector,  is  now  mostly  provided  by 
privately owned buses, taxis, and minivans, but with little regulation. It is constrained by lack of 
transport capacity; congestion; pollution; lack of accessibility; inadequate route coverage; poor 
road condition; and lack of depots, stops, and terminals as well as designated road space. The 
urban transport system needs integrated planning. Vehicle fleet support services are mostly 
privately  provided,  with  government  workshops  operating  poorly,  including  those  at  border 
points. Forms of regional transport depend on the state of the roads and the availability of 
vehicles.  People  and  goods  move  together,  blurring  distinction  between  passenger  and 
commercial freight traffic. Private agencies operate provincial and district routes. Some 165 
registered long-distance private bus companies are estimated to be operating—101 based in 
Kabul, 64 in the provinces—with a total of 14,007 buses, mostly old minibuses and vans. 
 
9.  The taxi system in Afghanistan is widespread and well organized. According to MOT, 24 
taxi  unions  registered  in  Kabul  and  27  in  the  provinces  have  a  total  of  29,131  vehicles. 
According to the Transport Sector Review, the real number of taxis in Kabul is perhaps 30,000. 
Taxis seem to operate freely, with little adherence to zonal or any other rules. In addition, 
intermediate size vehicles of all sizes and shapes transport passengers and goods. 
 
C.   Road Administration 
 
10.  Road administration is highly centralized. Before the protracted hostilities, the Ministry of 
Public Works (MPW), through its 15 departments, was virtually responsible for all government 
construction and maintenance, including roads and bridges, airports, public housing, and water 
supply.  A  number  of  MPW  construction  units  carried  out  all  aspects  of  planning,  design, 
construction,  and  maintenance.  Before  1992,  just  one  of  MPW’s  departments,  Road

Construction and Development, had more than 5,000 employees. In addition, MPW had a 
multitude of other responsibilities such as city planning and collection of road tolls. Theoretically, 
MPW retains all of these responsibilities. The Ministry of Rehabilitation and Rural Development 
is responsible for development of rural infrastructure, including rural roads. Municipalities are 
responsible for the construction and maintenance of urban roads. 
 
11.  Over the course of the conflict, the Government ministries lost a majority of their trained 
staff. In provinces where staff and equipment were retained, they were often under the influence 
of provincial governments and not fully under the control of ministry headquarters in Kabul. This 
situation is gradually being realigned as the central Government successfully extends its control 
outside Kabul to the provinces. The current staffing level of MPW is about 2,900: 900 are 
employed on a permanent basis, 1,900 are paid daily wages, and 140 are military officers. Most 
of the current staff require substantial skill enhancement to perform their duties. 
 
12.  To fill the capacity gap, most of the externally funded projects are being implemented 
with assistance of international consultants in project management. Civil works are packaged 
into large contracts and bid out through competitive procedures to private sector contractors. 
Consultants engaged by MPW supervise the works of contractors. MPW is being transformed 
into  a  lean  and  thin  organization  with  its  primary  task  being  nationwide  policy  formation, 
planning of the countrywide road network, setting of standards (including technical, safety, 
social, and environmental safeguards), regulation and enforcement functions, and management 
of roads under its jurisdiction. 
 
 
D.   Road Sector Revenues and Expenditures 
 
13.  Since 2002, with external assistance, the Government has been making massive efforts 
to reestablish the road network, particularly for regional highways, in order to facilitate provision 
of basic social services to remote provinces, provide security, and involve all the population in 
undertaking nation-building activities. Afghanistan is receiving extensive assistance from the 
international  aid  community  to  reconstruct  and  develop  the  road  network.  For  regional 
highways, almost $1.2 billion has been provided or committed to rehabilitate 3,100 km of roads. 
These rehabilitation works will be completed by 2007. For national highways, about $270 million 
has been committed to reconstruct and improve 1,200 km of roads. These commitments are 
mainly to rehabilitate damaged roads. 
 
14.  The Government is preparing the priority road development program for the next 10 
years  (2006–2015)  in  line  with  recommendations  of  the  road  master  plan  currently  being 
prepared with Asian Development Bank assistance. The least-cost option recommended by the 
road master plan envisages (i) upgrading 281 km of high-traffic regional highways to four lanes, 
(ii) improving 2,700 km of high priority national highways, and (iii) improving 5,000 km of high 
priority provincial roads. The required road expenditure to implement the recommended option 
is $1.7 billion excluding ongoing projects with financing resources secured. Considering the 
limited prospect for private sector financing of these large investments in the foreseeable future, 
the public sector and external assistance will continue to be responsible for meeting the road 
expenditure requirement.

under  construction  will  require  their  first  periodic  maintenance.  The  most  immediate

HIV/AIDS PREVENTION AND ANTI-HUMAN TRAFFICKING  
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The proposed project road from Mazar-e-Sharif to Dara-I-Suf and Yakawlang to Bamian 
constitutes the north–south link connecting the central region of Afghanistan. The project road 
runs  through  the  remotest  and  least  developed  areas  of  the  country.  Rehabilitating  and 
improving the north–south link will contribute to promoting increased connectivity and linkages 
for isolated communities, create employment opportunities for unskilled laborers involved in 
road construction and maintenance (with possible targeting of internally and/or internationally 
displaced persons and ex-combatants), promote increased access to basic social services 
(education and health), and support income-generating opportunities for poor households. Other 
than positive impacts on poverty reduction, improved transport network connectivity (and the 
related increased road traffic and mobility) will encourage the introduction of sex workers and 
migrant labors, leading to a potential increase in the spread of HIV/AIDS and human trafficking 
risks in the project area. Women’s greater exposure to HIV/AIDS, sexually transmitted infections 
(STIs), and, increasingly, human trafficking is acknowledged and forms the rationale for the 
proposed initiatives under this component. 
 
B.  The Current HIV/AIDS Situation 
 
2.  Afghanistan is, on the surface, a conservative Islamic country, making the issues of sex, 
gender relations, and HIV/AIDS sensitive issues to discuss. HIV/AIDS prevalence as reported 
by the Ministry of Public Health (MOPH) is 51 HIV cases and 4 deaths (as of 2006). Diagnostic 
capacity varies and the real number of cases may be far higher as screening has been limited to 
blood  donors.  Little  is  known  about  the  factors  that  influence  the  spread  of  HIV/AIDS  in 
Afghanistan.  However,  many  existing  vulnerability  factors  could  fuel  the  epidemic,  and 
contribute to women’s greater vulnerability to the risks and impacts of HIV/AIDS. These include 
the following: 
 
(i)  Low  status  of  women.  Two  decades  of  conflict  have  not  only  led  to  a 
breakdown of infrastructure and delivery of services in Afghanistan, but also 
contributed to the downward trend of women's rights. The gender development 
index is among the lowest in the world. According to a 2006 World Bank report, 
opportunities  available  to  Afghan  women  in  the  areas  of  health,  education, 
employment, and legal and political rights are extremely low by world standards. 
They lack access to information on how to protect themselves. Although little 
data is available, many women may be forced into sex work to support their 
families. 
 
(ii)  High number of refugees and displaced people. As a result of poverty, lack of 
amenities, and conflict situations, Afghanistan has the second largest number of 
refugees  in  the  world  after  Palestine.  According  to  the  United  Nations 
Development  Programme’s  Human  Development  Report,  2004,  3.4  million 
Afghans continue to remain outside the country. In addition, the southern and 
western parts of the country host nearly 200,000 internally displaced persons. 
Although little is known about the HIV risk behaviors of Afghan refugees and 
displaced people, such groups generally have little access to information about 
HIV/AIDS and are often vulnerable due to isolation from their families and lack of 
hope or the means to support themselves.

which is used to make heroin. Easy access to drugs could result in high use of

C.  The Current Human Trafficking Situation 
 
4.  Human  trafficking  is  the  forced  removal  and  migration  of  people  against  their  will. 
According to the International Organisation for Migration, Afghanistan is prone to both internal 
and international trafficking. Human trafficking victims are often women and children, usually 
destined  for  Middle  Eastern  countries.  Numerous  types  of  activities  are  related  to  human 
55trafficking, many are linked to poverty in the country. These include (i) commercial sex work, 
(ii) forced labor in the carpet industry and servitude, (iii) forced recruitment into armed groups, 
(iv) forced religious training, and (v) sale of body organs (as indicated by local nongovernment 
organizations [NGOs]). Poppy cultivation is also supposed to be a sign of poverty and human 
trafficking for labor, but people are reported to voluntarily do this work as it provides substantial 
financial return. With respect to this project, since cross-border traffic is not expected to use the 
project roads, the possibility of internal trafficking could materialize.

2.  Proposed  Design  Standards:  Cross  Section.  The  national  highway  network  is 
planned  to  promote  trade  and  economic  linkages;  extend  regional  highways  to  provincial 
capitals; and contribute to peace, security, stability, economic growth, and national integration. 
Most parts of the two sections are highly prioritized due to its significant function in the national 
highway network. In flat terrain sections, traffic speed is expected to be higher than on other 
minor roads. Based on these economic and safety features, flat sections with high traffic volume 
and in built-up areas will have a typical cross section designed for two traffic lanes of 3.50 m 
wide each, with two granular shoulders of 1.5 m and two verges of 0.5 m, with a total width of 
11.0 m.

through unavoidable constrained areas such as religious structures or confined river sides, 
reducing the carriage and shoulder width to 6.0 m and 0.50 m is recommended.

3.   Genesis 
 
Since rehabilitation of roads started after more than two decades of conflict, the focus of the 
road  rehabilitation  program  has  been  the  reconstruction  and  completion  of  the  regional 
highways. Once the current or planned projects are completed by 2008, the existing regional 
highway network will be improved to a two-lane bitumen-paved road standard, with certain four-
lane  sections  near  Kabul  and  Kandahar.  In  contrast,  over  90%  of  national  highways  and 
provincial roads are either earth or gravel, and over 60% are in a poor condition. Many of them

are motorable along the greater part of their length but are impassable at specific locations such 
as rivers and sections where severe erosion or landslides have occurred. Except for newly 
constructed bridges, most bridges and culverts along national highways and provincial roads 
are in bad condition. Many are in danger of collapse from heavily loaded vehicles or from being 
washed away.  
 
Anticipating regional highway work to be completed by 2008, the Government put its next 
priority to development of the north–south corridor and the east–west corridor, which connect 
the  ring  road  horizontally  and  perpendicularly  and  provide  better  access  to  people  in  the 
hinterland at the center of the country.  
 
During the first phase of road rehabilitation after resuming its operation in Afghanistan in 2002, 
ADB gave its priority attention to rehabilitation of regional highways, particularly the ring road, 
with  emphasis  on  trade  links  to  neighboring  countries,  including  bridges,  disintegrated 
pavements, drainage erosion protection, and routine maintenance. As rehabilitation of regional 
highways is completed, ADB is placing its next priority to connection of the ring road through the 
north–south  corridor  or  the  east–west  corridor  as  recommended  by  the  road  master  plan 
prepared with ADB assistance. The project roads comprise the north–south and east–west 
corridor, which connect the central hinterland of Afghanistan to the major cities such as Mazar-
e-Sharif and Kabul where the ring road passes. Bamian, the main focus of the JFPR component, 
is  renowned  for  its  abundant  historical  and  cultural  relics,  which  should  be  protected  and 
preserved.  Improved  road  connection  to  Bamian  will  generate  a  synergy  to  ongoing 
development partner activities to preserve such invaluable assets.  
 
4.   Innovation  
 
There are no innovations in the design of the project in terms of poverty reduction interventions, 
being primarily a road construction project. However, to the extent possible, local labor will be 
used to generate local employment. 
 
Improved roads will also lead to shift from subsistence agriculture to market-based production 
enabling farmers to grow perishable commercial products like vegetables and fruits allowing 
them to transport these goods at much shorter time. The farmers in the provinces would also be 
able to diversify their cropping patterns, cultivate high-value crops, grow larger marketable 
surpluses to improve their income-earning capacities as well as generate more agricultural 
wage employment, particularly benefiting the poor. 
 
Improved road conditions will lead to growth of affordable transport facilities and thus the poor, 
especially  women  and  children,  will  have  more  reliable,  affordable,  and  timely  access  to 
educational and medical facilities. Lower transportation costs will also increase mobility among 
the poor to find employment opportunities in other areas. Increased access to local and national 
markets will lead to growth of local trade, increased production activities, and reduced prices of 
agricultural commodities and other products.  
 
5.   Sustainability 
 
Routine road maintenance expenditures are projected to increase steadily as road projects are 
completed, from $8 million in 2006 to $25 million in 2015. Periodic maintenance will not be 
required until 2010, when the expenditure will increase significantly to about $45 million per year 
from  2011  to  2015  because  the  regional  and  national  highway  projects  currently  under 
construction will reach the stage requiring the first periodic maintenance.

The most immediate maintenance requirement is for special maintenance works on national 
highways and provincial roads of which maintenance has long been delayed, beginning with an 
estimated $26 million in 2006 and gradually decreasing to $14 million in 2015 as the backlog of 
work is eliminated. Over the period of 2006–2015, the need for special works will decrease while 
the need for routine and periodic maintenance will increase, approximately balancing each 
other. For the years 2006–2010, the average maintenance annual maintenance requirement 
including routine, periodic, and backlog maintenance ranges from $34 million to $47 million, 
while the same will increase to $87 million for the years of 2011–2015 because of the significant 
increase of periodic maintenance. 
 
The  expected  road  revenue,  however,  falls  far  short  of  the  required  road  maintenance 
expenditure. The main source of road revenue, road tolls which the Government will reinstate 
for rehabilitated regional highways, is expected to generate $13 million–$23 million for the 
period of 2006–2015 on the basis of the toll rate of $0.005 per passenger car equivalent per km. 
Even considering vehicle registration fees currently collected and expected to generate $3 
million–$6 million per year for the period of 2006–2015, the expected road revenue will be able 
to finance around 30%50% of road maintenance requirement.  
 
To  relieve  the  shortfall  of  road  revenue,  The  Government  will  evaluate  other  sustainable 
methods for revenue generation such as setting up a dedicated road maintenance fund based 
on fuel levies, vehicles licensing, and other road-user related taxes; and will complete this 
evaluation by December 2007. At present, fuel prices in Afghanistan rank among the lowest in 
the region (about $0.5 per liter) with no tax levied except customs duty of 9%, while taxes on 
fuel in other countries range from 13% to 70%. Based on fuel usage and estimated vehicle 
population, the total amount of fuel used for road transport vehicles is estimated as 582 million 
liters per year, which can translate into $291 million in expenditure for fuel consumed by road 
users. If a 10%–15% fuel tax is introduced, it will generate $29 million–$48 million of additional 
road  revenue,  which  will  be  sufficient  to  cover  the  shortfall  of  current  road  revenue.  The 
development partners’ local consultative group, consisting of major financiers such as the World 
Bank,  United  States  Agency  for  International  Development  (USAID),  and  Japan  Bank  for 
International Cooperation, considers introduction of fuel tax as one of its key agenda for policy 
dialogue and will continue its dialogue with the Government to secure stable financing sources 
for sustainable road maintenance.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Afghanistan: 
 
The Afghanistan Government has accorded highest priority to developing road infrastructure. Currently the country’s 
road network comprises regional highways (ring roads and links to neighboring countries) and several national 
highways. However, no roads connect the central region from the north to south, which has resulted in traffic having to 
use a circuitous route. This increases both travel distance and travel time. Thus the construction of a north–south link 
road will reduce travel distance and time, and promote economic growth in the region. The inadequate road system 
keeps many farmers dependent on subsistence agriculture with no, or limited, access to markets, education, and 
health care. The project roads run through the remotest and least developed areas of the country. Portions of the 
existing road are paved but most is merely mud truck tracks where most of the sections easily turn impassable after 
the rains. Rehabilitating and improving the north–south link will also contribute to employment creation, income 
generation for poor households, and rehabilitation of internally and/or internationally displaced persons and ex-
combatants, thus reducing the incidence of poverty in the project area. 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                        Poverty Classification: General intervention 
 
In Afghanistan, nearly 53% of the population are classified as poor1 and live on less than $1 a day. The project road 
passes through the provinces of Balkh, Samangan, and Bamian and will benefit a total population of 1,735,800.2. 
Before the war, these provinces were known for their agriculture, livestock, handicrafts, and carpets industry. The 
existing road condition is the biggest constraint as people are unable to transport their products to markets and 
currently crops are grown only on a small scale, which is enough for household consumption. Irrigation facilities are 
limited and few farmers still cultivate poppies to increase their income. Poverty in these provinces is estimated at 60%, 
with most of the population living in mud houses (80–95%) and the majority of households living without electricity, 
clean water, proper sanitation facilities, and garbage disposal. As per the data available, only 10%–11% of the 
households in these three provinces have access to clean water; only 10% in Balkh province have a garbage disposal 
system. The social assessment indicates that the population living along the proposed alignment is generally poor with 
about 48% having an annual income of less than $600 with an average household size of 9. The survey also indicates 
that 75% are engaged in subsistence agriculture and allied activities for their livelihood, while the rest have small 
businesses in the town areas.  
 
Afghanistan ranks 4th highest for under-5 mortality rate at 257 deaths/1,000; the infant mortality rate is at a high 
165/1,000. Among the three provinces Balkh has four hospitals, Samangan has only one provincial hospital, and 
Bamian has only one district hospital with a limited number of beds to cater to the entire population. The survey 
reveals that the local population in these provinces has to use private transport facilities to reach the hospitals, which 
is expensive due to poor road conditions and limited availability. Due to poor road conditions, some emergency cases 
could not reach the hospitals on time. Apart from difficulty accessing district and provincial hospitals, people travelled 
1–2 hours on foot to reach the nearest health center. Malnutrition among children is very common in the project area, 
while adults and children also suffer from diseases like malaria, diarrhoea, and bronchitis due to the unclean 
environment resulting from lack of clean water and air pollution. Lack of adequate and accessible educational facilities 
is another major problem in the project area. Although, the provinces have primary and secondary schools, only the 
population living near the towns send their children to school, while children living in smaller settlements are deprived 
of schooling due to poor road conditions and lack of transport facilities. Some schools lack proper buildings and 
teaching equipment. Poor road conditions and accessibility also constrain teachers and health personnel from working

acquired, the owner receives the (i) value of the land, (ii) value of residential houses and

states that the person who loses a residential land plot will receive a new plot of land of the

exchange under proper procedures. Thus, under the existing land acquisition law when 
private landholdings are acquired for public purposes, compensation is paid to the owner 
based on the category and location of the land, and the value of land for compensation is 
determined by the Council of Ministers. The decision is based on the recommendation of a 
committee consisting of the following (i) the landlord or person who uses the land or their 
representatives, (ii) official representative of the agency that needs to acquire the land (e.g., 
Ministry of Public Works), (iii) representative of the local municipality, (iv) representative of 
the Ministry of Finance, and (v) representative of the Ministry of Justice. The land acquisition 
process is initiated with the constitution of the committee. As land is acquired for a public 
purpose,  the  law  apparently  does  not  entertain  any  objection  to  the  acquisition  of  an 
individual’s property. However, if any dissatisfaction arises with the acquisition, which mostly 
relates to the value of compensation, the committee inquires into the matter and arrives at a 
solution. The whole process is based on a negotiated approach and as the affected person

G.  Consultation Meetings, Stakeholder Participation, and Grievance Redress 
 
12.  The project development and activities were discussed with the local communities 
during the consultation meetings at various project locations. The discussions were held with 
all the primary and secondary stakeholders including the local administration and land asset 
agriculture department, and with various other international and local agencies involved with 
rehabilitation  and  reconstruction  in  Afghanistan.  The  directly  affected  populations  were 
consulted  to  understand  their  concerns  regarding  the  road  construction  and  gather 
suggestions on the types of mitigation measures that should be considered to address the 
envisaged impacts. The consultations and discussions with the project-affected people will 
be  a  continuing  activity  throughout  the  implementation  stage  of  the  Project.  During 
implementation, MPW will be assisted in conducting the consultations by the nongovernment 
organization (NGO) that will be contracted for resettlement plan implementation. A summary 
of the resettlement plan and entitlement matrix will be translated into the local language 
(Dari) and disclosed to those affected and made available in local MPW offices, Afghanistan 
Resident Mission, and ADB website. The NGO will keep the people affected informed about 
the impacts, compensation, and assistance proposed for them; and facilitate addressing any 
grievances. Those affected will participate in all the decisions and implementation of the 
resettlement plan. They will be involved in the grievance redress committee to review and 
resolve any dispute concerning compensation and other resettlement benefits. Finally, on-
site  consultation  will  be  continuous  during  project  implementation  to  ensure  that  those 
affected receive their due entitlements/benefits. 
 
H.  Implementation Responsibilities and Cost Estimates 
 
13.  MPW, through the two project implementation units (PIUs) will be responsible for 
implementation of the resettlement plan. Each PIU will be headed by a project manager and 
an NGO will be appointed to implement the resettlement plan. Two officers deputed to the 
PIU  from  MPW  or  Land  Assets  of  the  Ministry  of  Agriculture  will  act  as  the  social 
development officers (SDO) and monitor resettlement plan implementation. The supervision 
consultants will also provide one international resettlement specialist and two domestic

resettlement specialists to assist the SDOs. The SDOs, PIU officials, and NGO staff will 
undergo 1 week of training on ADB’s policy on resettlement, and resettlement management 
and implementation provided by the international resettlement specialist. The appointed 
NGO will generally be located at the project road sites for carrying out implementation of the 
resettlement  plan.  In  Afghanistan,  finding  NGOs  with  prior  experience  in  handling 
resettlement issues is difficult; however a large number of NGOs working in the education, 
health, and other infrastructure sectors can be trained adequately to assist the PIUs in 
resettlement implementation. The resettlement implementation will commence from the end 
of 2007 and be completed by the last quarter of 2008. Since the Project will be implemented 
through a design and build contract, the international resettlement specialist supported by 
the domestic resettlement specialists will be responsible for assisting the PIUs in updating 
the resettlement plan based on detailed design and submit it to ADB for approval. 
 
14.  Due to the prolonged war situation in Afghanistan and poor land record system, a 
land management committee will be formed at the central level and will include members 
from the Supreme Court, MPW, Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Energy and Water, and the 
Geology and Cartography Department. The primary task of the committee will be to resolve 
issues related to land records and ownership. Following loan negotiations, a grievance 
redress committee will be constituted for each district, comprising (i) a representative of 
those affected, (ii) a representative of the local administration (the chief administrator from 
the office of the governor), (iii) a representative from MPW, and (iv) a representative from the 
local legal department. The grievance, if any, will be put forward to this committee and a 
decision should be taken within 7–10 working days. In the case of the absence of any of the 
members during the decision-making process, an appropriate candidate will be nominated 
by the original representative. This is only to hasten the process of decision-making and 
facilitate the civil works. Presently the appeal mechanism available in rural areas includes 
the district commissioner and the district police chief, who in case of complaints by the 
people  resolves  such  conflicting  issues  through  individual  and  local  consultations.  The 
proposed  grievance  redress  committee  includes  a  representative  from  the  local 
administration  and  the  affected  individual.  Therefore,  grievances  are  expected  to  be 
redressed locally within the existing framework. 
 
15.  This is the first project to involve land acquisition. Consultations were carried out with 
the deputy minister, Land Assets, Ministry of Agriculture, and local officials to identify the 
time frame and method of assessment of compensation for land and assets. Discussions 
revealed that land acquisition will take less time in rural areas. Since the country has no 
similar experience with regard to assessing and paying compensation at replacement rate in 
rural areas, where the market for land is minimal, the ministry and local officials confirmed 
that the method of assessment is based on a negotiated approach as is the case between a 
willing seller and willing buyer.  
 
16.  The  estimated  cost  of  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  is  $2.0  million.  The 
Government will finance the land acquisition of $1.0 million and ADB the resettlement cost of 
$1.0 million. The unit values of compensation and assistance were calculated based on the 
information gathered during the social surveys from the local administration officials and the 
project-affected  community.  MPW  will  provide  the  entire  fund  for  land  acquisition  and 
resettlement activities. The PIUs will ensure that resettlement budgets are delivered on time 
to the implementing NGO for timely implementation of the resettlement plan. Individual 
entitlements on a household basis will be processed by the NGO based on confirmed 
census/SES data. Each entitled person will receive an identity card. All land acquisition 
payments  and  assistances  will  be  paid  to  those  affected  at  least  3  month’s  prior  to 
relocation, and  will  be  completed  before  possession  of land  and other  assets  prior  to 
commencement of civil works.

I.  Monitoring Arrangements 
 
17.  MPW will supervise and monitor implementation of the resettlement plan internally 
through the SDOs in the PIUs supported by the resettlement specialist from the supervision 
consultants. The SDOs will report to ADB on a quarterly basis during implementation of the 
resettlement plan. The monitoring report will deal with all aspects of relocation, resettlement, 
and rehabilitation of the households. The NGO implementing the resettlement plan will 
conduct field monitoring on a monthly basis, assess progress in the field; and prepare the 
monthly report for the SDOs. An external monitor will be engaged by MPW to submit 
biannual reports and provide feedback on resettlement plan implementation to both MPW 
and ADB. External monitors will be hired by MPW with ADB concurrence within 3 months 
after loan approval. A set of monitoring indicators and terms of reference for the external 
evaluation agency has been developed and included in the resettlement plan.

SUMMARY OF ECONOMIC ASSESSMENT 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The  road  components  of  the  Project  comprise  improvement  to  two  sections  of  the 
Mazar-e-Sharif  and  Bamian/Panjab  road:  between  Mazar-e-Sharif–Dara-i-Suf,  and  between 
Bamian–Yakawlang. Except for the 17 kilometer (km) section between Mazar-e-Sharif and Kota 
Baraq, the surface of the existing road is earth or gravel, is in poor condition, and requires 
reconstruction. 
 
2.  The  analysis  used  the  highway  design  and  maintenance  model  (HDM4)  with 
modification  for  conditions  in  Afghanistan.  Data  under  the  same  conditions  in  neighboring 
countries  were  adopted  for  unavailable  input  data.  Economic  evaluation  was  made  by 
comparing two cases of with and without the Project, which are defined as follows: 
 
(i)  Without the Project. The without-project scenario leaves all planned alignments 
in  the  current  construction  status,  requiring  only  routine  and  periodic 
maintenance. No capital investment costs are involved. Gravel roads will have 
routine and limited periodic maintenance (grading and spot regraveling) of the 
gravel roads. Paved roads will have routine and periodic maintenance in the form 
of patching and sealing.  
 
(ii)  With the Project. The with-project case will construct two-lane paved road over 
the whole stretch of the sections and reconstruct the 17 km of paved road. The 
road will have two types of treatments: (i) construction of asphalt-concrete road, 
and (ii) maintenance of the paved road in the form of patching, sealing, and 
overlay  in  accordance  with  road  deterioration,  and  routine  maintenance.  In 
addition,  gravel  roads  will  have  maintenance  before  upgrading  to  asphalt-
concrete. 
 
3.  The project road was evaluated up to and including 2027. The improved road will reduce 
operating costs and travel time, which will lead to a stimulus to economic growth in the project 
area. All benefits and costs are expressed in 2006 constant prices.

9.  The increase of traffic generated by the road improvement is assumed to be 20% for the 
Kota Baraq–Pul-e-Baraq section, 25% for the Pul-e-Baraq–Dara-i-Suf section, and 50% for the

C.  Costs 
 
14.  The Project’s economic costs were derived from the financial costs and include the cost 
for construction and maintenance. Economic costs exclude price contingencies, taxes, and 
duties. Afghanistan currently does not apply any taxes other than import duties. The foreign 
exchange rate does not have any significant distortions. Based on this, a conversion factor of 
0.95 is used to convert the financial cost of nontradables to economic costs. A residual value is 
assumed  to  be  10%–30%  with  a  higher  residual  value  assumed  where  more 
cutting/mountainous sections are involved. 
 
D.  Benefits 
 
15.  The main quantifiable benefits of the investment are (i) savings in vehicle operating 
costs and (ii) savings in travel time. Vehicle operating cost savings were calculated using the 
highway design and maintenance model for each vehicle type. All the input data is based on 
recent road feasibility studies in Afghanistan. The benefits for generated traffic are considered to 
be 50% of those for normal traffic.

roughness index (IRI) of 8 m/km and spot graveling every year for gravel roads to keep the 
surface condition at the minimum level of an IRI of 20. For the with-project case, overlay is 
conduced when the surface roughness of the road reaches an IRI of 5 m/km.
